intro: Oenothera hartwegii subsp. maccartii, commonly known as the Maccarthy's evening primrose, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It is characterized by its yellow to orange flowers that bloom in the evening, attracting nocturnal pollinators such as moths. The plant typically grows in sandy or gravelly soils and is adapted to arid environments. It has hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves, and its flowers have a distinctive tubular shape. This subspecies is part of the Onagraceae family and is known for its ecological importance in supporting local insect populations.
